description: SPM Knowledge Base Final Expansion - Completing 1,000+ cards

cards.definition: Evaluating the total revenue opportunity within a market segment or territory.
cards.whyItMatters: Foundation for fair quota allocation and resource deployment.
cards.howItWorks: Analyze account data → Estimate wallet share → Calculate potential → Sum by territory.
cards.example: Territory has 200 accounts with $10M estimated potential. Current penetration 20% = $8M growth opportunity.

cards.definition: Categorizing accounts into tiers based on value, potential, or strategic importance.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables differentiated coverage and service levels.
cards.howItWorks: Define tier criteria → Score accounts → Assign tiers → Apply coverage model per tier.
cards.example: Tier 1: >$1M potential (50 accounts, dedicated AE). Tier 2: $250K-$1M (500 accounts, shared coverage).

cards.definition: The formal specification of responsibilities, competencies, and compensation for a sales position.
cards.whyItMatters: Clear roles enable appropriate compensation design and performance expectations.
cards.howItWorks: Define responsibilities → Specify competencies → Set leveling criteria → Design compensation.
cards.example: Enterprise AE: Manages strategic accounts, closes complex deals, $250-350K OTE, requires 5+ years experience.

cards.definition: The process of moving a sales rep from one role to another, with associated quota and comp changes.
cards.whyItMatters: Smooth transitions maintain performance and retention.
cards.howItWorks: Evaluate readiness → Define transition date → Adjust quotas → Update compensation → Support onboarding.
cards.example: SDR promoted to AE: Transition April 1, 3-month ramp quota, new plan effective immediately.

cards.definition: A framework for organizing sales roles into levels based on scope, complexity, and experience.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables consistent compensation and career progression.
cards.howItWorks: Define levels (Associate, Senior, Principal) → Specify criteria per level → Map compensation bands.
cards.example: AE Level 1: 0-2 years, $200K OTE. Level 2: 2-5 years, $250K OTE. Level 3: 5+ years, $300K OTE.

cards.definition: The systematic approach used to determine individual sales quotas.
cards.whyItMatters: Fair, transparent methodology increases quota acceptance.
cards.howItWorks: Select approach → Apply consistently → Document rationale → Communicate to reps.
cards.example: Methodology: Territory potential (50%) + historical performance (30%) + market growth (20%) = individual quota.

cards.definition: The process of applying plan rules to transactions to determine commission amounts.
cards.whyItMatters: Accuracy is critical for trust and financial reporting.
cards.howItWorks: Match transactions to reps → Apply rates and modifiers → Calculate amounts → Generate results.
cards.example: $100K deal × 5% rate × 1.2 accelerator (above quota) = $6,000 commission.

cards.definition: Commission rates that increase at defined performance thresholds.
cards.whyItMatters: Creates progressive incentive for higher performance.
cards.howItWorks: Define thresholds → Set rate at each level → Apply incrementally as thresholds crossed.
cards.example: 0-100% quota: 5%. 100-150%: 7%. 150%+: 10%. Each band earns at its specific rate.

cards.definition: Different commission rates applied to different products or services.
cards.whyItMatters: Steers selling behavior toward strategic products.
cards.howItWorks: Assign rate to each product → Apply rate based on product sold → May vary by quota attainment.
cards.example: Core product: 5%. New product launch: 8%. Services: 3%. Strategic product: 10%.

cards.definition: Additional compensation for registering opportunities early in the sales cycle.
cards.whyItMatters: Improves pipeline visibility and forecasting accuracy.
cards.howItWorks: Rep registers deal within X days of creation → If deal closes, additional bonus paid → May require minimum size.
cards.example: Register within 30 days of first meeting, deal closes → $500 bonus on top of standard commission.

cards.definition: A bonus paid to all members of a team based on collective performance.
cards.whyItMatters: Encourages collaboration and shared accountability.
cards.howItWorks: Team performance measured → If threshold met, bonus pool funded → Distributed to team members.
cards.example: Team hits 110% of collective quota → $50K bonus pool distributed equally among 10 team members = $5K each.

cards.definition: A bonus paid based on performance during a specific quarter.
cards.whyItMatters: Creates focus on shorter-term goals and more frequent rewards.
cards.howItWorks: Measure quarterly performance → Compare to target → Calculate bonus → Pay after quarter close.
cards.example: Hit 100% quarterly quota = $10K bonus. 120% = $15K bonus. Paid within 30 days of quarter end.

cards.definition: A bonus paid based on full-year performance, often in addition to ongoing commissions.
cards.whyItMatters: Encourages sustained performance throughout the year.
cards.howItWorks: Full-year performance measured → Compare to annual target → Calculate bonus → Pay after year close.
cards.example: Exceed 100% annual quota: Additional 2% of total revenue as annual bonus. 120% gets 4%.

cards.definition: Additional compensation specifically for acquiring new customer logos.
cards.whyItMatters: Drives new customer acquisition which may be harder than expansion.
cards.howItWorks: New customer closed → Bonus paid on top of standard commission → May have minimum deal size.
cards.example: New logo bonus: $2,000 per new customer. Minimum first-year value $25K to qualify.

cards.definition: The formal process for reviewing and approving compensation plans before implementation.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures plans are financially sound, legally compliant, and strategically aligned.
cards.howItWorks: Draft plan → Financial review → Legal review → Leadership approval → Documentation.
cards.example: 2026 plans: Sales Ops drafts → Finance models cost → Legal reviews → CRO and CFO approve → Published to reps.

cards.definition: Managing different versions of compensation plans with clear effective dates.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables accurate historical calculations and audit support.
cards.howItWorks: Each change creates new version → Effective dates tracked → Historical versions retained.
cards.example: Plan v1.0 effective Jan 1, v1.1 effective April 1 (rate change), v2.0 effective Jan 1 next year.

cards.definition: Verifying that commission calculations match payments and financial records.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures accuracy and supports financial reporting.
cards.howItWorks: Compare calculations to payments → Identify discrepancies → Investigate and resolve → Document.
cards.example: Monthly reconciliation: ICM shows $2.1M, payroll paid $2.0M. Investigate $100K variance. Found timing issue.

cards.definition: Maintaining a log of all approved exceptions to standard compensation policies.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables pattern analysis and policy improvement.
cards.howItWorks: Exception approved → Logged with details → Analyzed periodically → Policy updated if pattern emerges.
cards.example: Q4 exception log: 15 quota relief requests (12 approved), 8 rate exceptions (5 approved). Analyze for patterns.

cards.definition: A governance body responsible for compensation policy decisions and oversight.
cards.whyItMatters: Provides formal structure for compensation governance.
cards.howItWorks: Regular meetings → Review policies and exceptions → Make decisions → Document and communicate.
cards.example: Monthly comp committee: Sales Ops, Finance, HR, Legal. Reviews plan changes, approves exceptions >$25K.

cards.definition: Tracking quota attainment over time to identify patterns and predict outcomes.
cards.whyItMatters: Early warning system for performance issues.
cards.howItWorks: Plot attainment by period → Identify trends → Project year-end outcome → Take action.
cards.example: Rep at 40% through half year = on track for 80% annual. Trending down from Q1 → intervention needed.

cards.definition: Projecting future commission expenses based on pipeline and performance trends.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical for financial planning and budgeting.
cards.howItWorks: Forecast revenue → Apply commission rates → Model scenarios → Update regularly.
cards.example: Q4 forecast: $50M revenue at 6% effective rate = $3M commission expense. Budget is $2.8M → over budget risk.

cards.definition: A comprehensive view of an individual rep's performance across multiple metrics.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables holistic performance assessment and coaching.
cards.howItWorks: Aggregate key metrics → Display in single view → Enable drill-down → Update in real-time.
cards.example: Scorecard shows: Quota attainment 95%, pipeline 3.5x, win rate 28%, activity score 85, forecast accuracy 90%.

cards.definition: A consolidated view of team performance for sales managers.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables managers to monitor and coach their teams effectively.
cards.howItWorks: Aggregate team metrics → Highlight issues → Enable rep drill-down → Support coaching.
cards.example: Dashboard shows: Team at 92% of quota, 2 reps below 70%, pipeline gap for Q4, forecast accuracy by rep.

cards.definition: High-level performance summary for sales leadership.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables strategic oversight without operational detail.
cards.howItWorks: Aggregate company/region metrics → Show trends and forecasts → Highlight risks → Enable drill-down.
cards.example: CRO dashboard: Revenue vs. target, cost of sales %, quota achievement distribution, forecast accuracy, top/bottom performers.

cards.definition: The choice between cloud-hosted SaaS and on-premise deployment for ICM systems.
cards.whyItMatters: Significant impact on cost, security, and maintenance.
cards.howItWorks: Cloud: Vendor-hosted, subscription model. On-premise: Customer-hosted, perpetual license.
cards.example: Cloud ICM: $50/user/month, vendor maintains. On-premise: $500K upfront, customer maintains.

cards.definition: The choice between processing transactions in periodic batches or as they occur.
cards.whyItMatters: Affects rep visibility and system performance.
cards.howItWorks: Batch: Transactions accumulated, processed periodically. Real-time: Each transaction processed immediately.
cards.example: Batch: Nightly processing at 2am. Real-time: Commission visible within minutes of deal close.

cards.definition: Connecting ICM systems to enterprise data warehouses for advanced analytics.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables cross-functional analytics and historical trending.
cards.howItWorks: Extract ICM data → Transform for warehouse → Load to DW → Enable analytics tools.
cards.example: Nightly extract of commission data to Snowflake → Tableau dashboards combine with CRM and finance data.

cards.definition: Authentication allowing users to access ICM with corporate credentials.
cards.whyItMatters: Improves security and user experience.
cards.howItWorks: User authenticates with corporate identity → Token passed to ICM → Access granted.
cards.example: Rep clicks ICM link → Redirected to Okta → Authenticates with corporate credentials → Returns to ICM logged in.

cards.definition: Limiting system access based on user roles.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures data security and appropriate access.
cards.howItWorks: Define roles → Assign permissions per role → Assign users to roles → Enforce access.
cards.example: Roles: Rep (view own data), Manager (view team), Admin (full access), Auditor (read-only all).

cards.definition: The total expected cash compensation including base salary and target incentive.
cards.whyItMatters: Primary metric for market benchmarking and internal equity.
cards.howItWorks: TTC = Base Salary + Target Incentive (at 100% attainment).
cards.example: Enterprise AE TTC: $140K base + $140K target incentive = $280K TTC.

cards.definition: The variable compensation amount expected when achieving 100% of quota.
cards.whyItMatters: Defines the at-risk portion of compensation and incentive potential.
cards.howItWorks: Target Incentive = TTC × (1 - Base Salary %)
cards.example: TTC $280K with 50/50 mix → Target Incentive = $140K.

cards.definition: External data sources used to benchmark compensation against market.
cards.whyItMatters: Quality data enables competitive positioning.
cards.howItWorks: Select surveys → Participate or purchase → Match roles → Analyze positioning.
cards.example: Sources: Radford, Mercer, CompAnalyst, Glassdoor, LinkedIn Salary Insights, industry-specific surveys.

cards.definition: Setting pay levels at specific market percentiles (e.g., 50th, 75th).
cards.whyItMatters: Defines competitive stance in talent market.
cards.howItWorks: Select target percentile → Benchmark current pay → Adjust to target → Monitor market changes.
cards.example: Strategy: Target 50th percentile for base, 75th for top performer total comp.

cards.definition: Measuring whether incentive plans drive intended behaviors and outcomes.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures compensation investment delivers value.
cards.howItWorks: Define expected behaviors → Measure before/after → Correlate to plan changes → Calculate ROI.
cards.example: Added new product accelerator → New product sales up 40% → At 15% cost increase → Positive ROI.

cards.definition: The process of documenting business requirements for compensation system implementation.
cards.whyItMatters: Comprehensive requirements prevent costly rework.
cards.howItWorks: Interview stakeholders → Document current state → Define future state → Identify gaps → Prioritize.
cards.example: Requirements document: 50 plan rules, 20 integrations, 15 reports, 5 workflow requirements.

cards.definition: Translating business requirements into technical system design.
cards.whyItMatters: Good design enables accurate implementation.
cards.howItWorks: Map requirements to system capabilities → Design data model → Plan integrations → Document approach.
cards.example: Design document: Data model, calculation logic, integration architecture, security model, user workflows.

cards.definition: Cleaning and standardizing data before migrating to a new compensation system.
cards.whyItMatters: Bad data produces bad calculations; cleanse before migration.
cards.howItWorks: Profile data quality → Identify issues → Cleanse and standardize → Validate → Document transformations.
cards.example: Found: 500 duplicate reps, 200 missing territories, 50 invalid rates. Cleansed before migration.

cards.definition: Testing connections between the compensation system and other enterprise applications.
cards.whyItMatters: Integration failures cause data issues and calculation errors.
cards.howItWorks: Test each integration point → Validate data flow → Test error handling → Document results.
cards.example: CRM integration test: Send 100 test transactions → Verify all received → Check data accuracy → Test error scenarios.

cards.definition: Testing system performance under expected and peak load conditions.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures system can handle production volumes.
cards.howItWorks: Define load scenarios → Execute tests → Measure response times → Identify bottlenecks → Optimize.
cards.example: Load test: 1M transactions, 1000 concurrent users. Target: Complete calculations in <1 hour.

cards.definition: Circumstances under which earned or unearned commissions may be forfeited.
cards.whyItMatters: Must be legally compliant; varies significantly by state.
cards.howItWorks: Define forfeiture events → Document in plan → Apply consistently → Comply with state law.
cards.example: Forfeiture events: Termination for cause, violation of policies, clawback triggers. Subject to state law limits.

cards.definition: Language preserving company's right to modify or discontinue compensation plans.
cards.whyItMatters: Protects flexibility while maintaining rep trust.
cards.howItWorks: Include reservation of rights → Specify modification process → Balance with clear commitments.
cards.example: Plan language: 'Company reserves the right to modify this plan with 30 days notice. Earned commissions not affected.'

cards.definition: How commission plans interact with non-compete agreements.
cards.whyItMatters: Some states require continued commission payment during non-compete.
cards.howItWorks: Evaluate state law → Structure commissions appropriately → Consider garden leave.
cards.example: Massachusetts: If non-compete enforced, may need to continue commission payments. Structure plan accordingly.

cards.definition: The tax withholding and reporting requirements for commission payments.
cards.whyItMatters: Incorrect withholding creates liability for employer and employee.
cards.howItWorks: Apply supplemental wage withholding rates → Report on W-2 → Comply with state requirements.
cards.example: Federal supplemental rate 22% (or aggregate method). State rates vary. Include in total wages for FICA.

cards.definition: Ensuring compensation practices don't discriminate based on protected characteristics.
cards.whyItMatters: Legal requirement with significant penalty exposure.
cards.howItWorks: Analyze pay by demographics → Identify unexplained gaps → Remediate → Monitor ongoing.
cards.example: Annual pay equity analysis: Control for tenure, performance, role. Identify gaps >5% for review.

cards.definition: Pipeline value adjusted by probability of close at each stage.
cards.whyItMatters: More accurate view of expected revenue than raw pipeline.
cards.howItWorks: Each opportunity × stage probability = weighted value. Sum weighted values = expected revenue.
cards.example: Deal A: $100K at 80% probability = $80K weighted. Deal B: $200K at 25% = $50K. Total weighted: $130K.

cards.definition: Defined stages through which opportunities progress from initial contact to close.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables pipeline management, forecasting, and process analysis.
cards.howItWorks: Define stages → Assign exit criteria → Track progression → Analyze conversion rates.
cards.example: Stages: Discovery (10%) → Qualification (25%) → Proposal (50%) → Negotiation (75%) → Closed (100%).

cards.definition: Line-by-line detail of transactions contributing to commission earnings.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables rep verification and reduces disputes.
cards.howItWorks: List each transaction → Show rate applied → Show calculation → Enable drill-down.
cards.example: Statement shows: Deal ABC, $100K, New Business rate 6%, attainment multiplier 1.2x, commission $7,200.

cards.definition: Total commission earnings accumulated from the start of the year.
cards.whyItMatters: Key metric for tracking progress toward annual targets.
cards.howItWorks: Sum all earnings from January 1 through current date → Compare to prorated annual target.
cards.example: Through June 30: YTD earnings $75K. Annual target $150K. 50% of year = on track.

cards.definition: A centralized location for all compensation policies and procedures.
cards.whyItMatters: Single source of truth for governance documentation.
cards.howItWorks: Store all policies → Version control → Enable search → Control access.
cards.example: Repository contains: Commission policy, exception process, clawback policy, dispute procedure, plan documents.

cards.definition: Regular review of compensation program performance and issues.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables proactive identification and resolution of issues.
cards.howItWorks: Gather metrics → Analyze trends → Review exceptions → Identify issues → Plan actions.
cards.example: Quarterly review: Attainment distribution, exception patterns, cost trends, dispute analysis, recommendations.

cards.definition: Using algorithms to identify unusual patterns in compensation data.
cards.whyItMatters: Catches errors and fraud that manual review might miss.
cards.howItWorks: Define normal patterns → Apply statistical methods → Flag outliers → Investigate.
cards.example: Detected: Rep with $50K single commission when average is $5K. Investigation found duplicate credit.

cards.definition: Tracking adherence to compensation policies and identifying violations.
cards.whyItMatters: Ensures policies are followed consistently.
cards.howItWorks: Define compliance rules → Monitor transactions → Flag violations → Report and remediate.
cards.example: Monitoring: Exception approvals, rate overrides, manual adjustments, policy deviations. Monthly compliance report.

cards.definition: A non-production environment for testing changes before deployment.
cards.whyItMatters: Enables safe testing without affecting production.
cards.howItWorks: Mirror production setup → Test changes → Validate results → Promote to production.
cards.example: Rate change: Test in sandbox with sample data → Verify calculations → Approve → Promote to production.

cards.definition: System capabilities for reps to submit and track compensation inquiries.
cards.whyItMatters: Streamlines dispute process and improves resolution.
cards.howItWorks: Rep submits inquiry → Routed to admin → Investigated → Resolved → Rep notified.
cards.example: Inquiry portal: Submit question, attach evidence, track status, receive resolution, rate satisfaction.

cards.definition: System capabilities for recording all changes and actions.
cards.whyItMatters: Required for SOX compliance and forensic analysis.
cards.howItWorks: Log all changes → Capture who, what, when → Immutable storage → Enable reporting.
cards.example: Audit log shows: User JSmith changed quota from $1M to $1.2M on 2026-01-15 at 10:30 AM.

cards.definition: The range of acceptable pay for a given job level or role.
cards.whyItMatters: Provides framework for consistent and equitable pay decisions.
cards.howItWorks: Define range (min, mid, max) → Place individuals within range → Manage progression.
cards.example: AE Level 2 band: Min $200K, Mid $250K, Max $300K OTE. Individual placement based on experience/performance.

cards.definition: How compensation increases over time through merit, promotion, or market adjustments.
cards.whyItMatters: Affects retention and career development.
cards.howItWorks: Annual merit increases → Promotion increases → Market adjustments → Manage within bands.
cards.example: Progression: Annual merit 3-5% based on performance. Promotion: 10-15% increase. Market adjustment: As needed.

cards.definition: An individual's pay compared to the midpoint of their pay range.
cards.whyItMatters: Indicates internal equity and progression opportunity.
cards.howItWorks: Compa-ratio = Actual Pay ÷ Range Midpoint × 100. 100% = at midpoint.
cards.example: Rep at $225K, midpoint $250K. Compa-ratio = 90%. Below midpoint, room for progression.

cards.definition: A plan for reverting to the previous system if go-live fails.
cards.whyItMatters: Critical risk mitigation for system implementations.
cards.howItWorks: Define rollback triggers → Document steps → Test procedure → Maintain old system → Execute if needed.
cards.example: Rollback triggers: >10% calculation variance, system unavailable >4 hours, critical data loss.

cards.definition: A formal review after implementation to capture lessons learned.
cards.whyItMatters: Improves future implementations and identifies ongoing issues.
cards.howItWorks: Gather feedback → Analyze what worked/didn't → Document lessons → Plan improvements.
cards.example: PIR findings: Parallel run too short, training insufficient, some integrations unstable. Action plan created.

cards.definition: The requirement for sales reps to formally acknowledge receipt of compensation plan.
cards.whyItMatters: Legally required in many states; protects against disputes.
cards.howItWorks: Present plan → Rep reviews → Rep signs acknowledgment → Retain record.
cards.example: California requires signed acknowledgment. System tracks: Plan delivered Jan 15, Acknowledged Jan 20.

cards.definition: Deadlines by which reps must raise compensation disputes.
cards.whyItMatters: Provides certainty for both parties; may be limited by state law.
cards.howItWorks: Define time limit → Communicate in plan → Track compliance → Process timely disputes.
cards.example: Plan states: Disputes must be raised within 60 days of payment. Subject to state law minimums.

cards.definition: Maintaining accurate, current pipeline data by removing stale opportunities.
cards.whyItMatters: Accurate pipeline enables accurate forecasting and capacity planning.
cards.howItWorks: Define stale criteria → Regular review → Close or update stale deals → Report compliance.
cards.example: Hygiene rules: No activity in 30 days = review required. Close date in past = must update or close.

cards.definition: Regular meeting to review pipeline and update sales forecast.
cards.whyItMatters: Drives forecast accuracy and identifies risks early.
cards.howItWorks: Review each opportunity → Update stage/amount → Discuss risks → Commit forecast.
cards.example: Weekly forecast call: Review top 20 deals, update stages, identify blockers, adjust forecast.

cards.definition: The distinction between quota attainment percentage and actual commission earnings.
cards.whyItMatters: Helps reps understand relationship between performance and pay.
cards.howItWorks: Attainment = Performance ÷ Quota. Earnings determined by rates, accelerators, modifiers.
cards.example: Rep at 110% attainment. Base rate 5%, accelerator 1.5x above 100%. Earnings > 110% of target due to accelerator.

cards.definition: A question from a rep about their compensation calculation.
cards.whyItMatters: Efficient inquiry handling builds trust and identifies issues.
cards.howItWorks: Rep submits question → Admin investigates → Responds with explanation or adjustment.
cards.example: Inquiry: 'Why didn't I get credit for Deal X?' Response: 'Deal credited to prior territory owner per carve-out policy.'

cards.definition: Controls over manual changes to compensation calculations.
cards.whyItMatters: Manual adjustments bypass system controls; require extra scrutiny.
cards.howItWorks: Define allowable adjustments → Require approval → Document rationale → Audit regularly.
cards.example: Manual adjustment policy: Requires manager approval <$5K, director >$5K, VP >$25K. Full audit trail.

cards.definition: Periodic review of user access to compensation systems.
cards.whyItMatters: SOX requirement; prevents unauthorized access.
cards.howItWorks: Extract user list → Review appropriateness → Remove inappropriate access → Document review.
cards.example: Quarterly access review: 50 users reviewed. 3 terminated employees removed. 2 role changes updated.

cards.definition: The difference between budgeted and actual commission costs.
cards.whyItMatters: Key metric for financial management.
cards.howItWorks: Actual cost - Budget = Variance. Analyze drivers of variance.
cards.example: Q3 commission: Budget $3M, Actual $3.5M, Variance +$500K (17% over). Driver: High performance on new product.

cards.definition: A visual representation of how payouts are distributed across the sales team.
cards.whyItMatters: Reveals plan health and identifies outliers.
cards.howItWorks: Plot payout amounts → Show distribution shape → Compare to expected → Identify anomalies.
cards.example: Distribution shows: 10% below floor, 50% at target, 30% above target, 10% at cap. Healthy distribution.

cards.definition: The process of delivering commission statements to sales reps.
cards.whyItMatters: Timely, secure delivery builds trust.
cards.howItWorks: Generate statements → Notify reps → Provide secure access → Track views.
cards.example: Monthly process: Statements generated by 5th, email notification sent, accessible in portal, 90% view rate.

cards.definition: Documentation helping users understand and use the compensation system.
cards.whyItMatters: Good documentation reduces support burden and improves adoption.
cards.howItWorks: Create role-based guides → Make searchable → Keep current → Gather feedback.
cards.example: Help system: Rep guide (view statements), Manager guide (team reporting), Admin guide (system management).

cards.definition: A comprehensive view of all compensation and benefits provided to an employee.
cards.whyItMatters: Helps employees understand full value of their compensation.
cards.howItWorks: Aggregate all comp elements → Present in unified view → Communicate total value.
cards.example: TRS shows: Base $140K, Commission $150K, Benefits $30K, 401K match $10K. Total value: $330K.

cards.definition: The process of communicating compensation plan details to the sales team.
cards.whyItMatters: Effective communication drives understanding and buy-in.
cards.howItWorks: Develop materials → Train managers → Conduct rollout sessions → Provide resources → Gather feedback.
cards.example: Plan rollout: Executive announcement, manager training, rep town hall, 1:1 reviews, FAQ document.
